body.p: What does this data tell you about the likelihood of this patient having coronary artery disease (CAD)?

multiple_choice.choice: A. CAD is unlikely because LDL levels are within normal range
B. CAD is unlikely because fibrinogen levels are within normal range
C. Likely because total cholesterol levels are high

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although LDLs (low density lipoproteins) are a risk factor for CAD, they are not the only molecule that can contribute to this condition.
Incorrect. Although high fibrinogen levels can be a marker of CAD, a single marker is often not enough to determine the likelihood (or not) of CAD.
Incorrect. Although total cholesterol levels are slightly greater than normal levels, LDL counts are more indicative of coronary heart disease.
Correct. This person’s blood chemistries, taken as a group, do not contain risk factors for CAD.

hint.p: Coronary heart disease is the narrowing of blood vessels that supply oxygenated blood to the heart.

body.p: How could high levels of cholesterol increase a person’s risk of heart disease?

multiple_choice.choice: Results in high levels of HDLs
Results in low levels of LDLs
Results in high levels of hormones that cause vasoconstriction

feedback.p: Correct. High levels of cholesterol can lead to atherosclerosis and impede blood flow to the heart.
Incorrect. HDLs (high density lipoproteins) remove excess cholesterol from the walls of blood vessels, which would allow unimpeded blood flow.

Incorrect. LDLs (low density lipoproteins) increase when a person has high levels of cholesterol in their body. LDLs can deposit cholesterol in the walls of blood vessels, leading to atherosclerortic plaque development.
Incorrect. Although cholesterol is vital toward synthesis of many steroid hormones, these hormones typically do not cause vasoconstriction.

hint.p: In healthy individuals, cholesterol is a vital component of cell membranes, but excess cholesterol accumulates someplace else.

body.p: Compared to the control image of a healthy heart, what appears abnormal in the patient’s MRI?

feedback.p: The walls of the patient’s ventricles appear to be thickened as compared to that in the healthy control. Known as ventricular hypertrophy, this causes an increase in the muscle mass of the heart. However, the increased muscle can decrease the volume of the ventricle, leading to decreased stroke volume when severe. It also leads to an increased need for oxygen, placing it at higher risk of myocardial infarction.

body.p: What are the advantages of cardiac MRIs?

feedback.p: MRIs are advantageous because of the high contrast resolution they offer. This allows for differentiation between different types of tissue, as well as blood. Thus, different types of cardiac anatomy can be observed without administering contrast media. Additionally, patients are not exposed to potentially harmful radiation in MRIs. The cardiac MRI is a very useful tool for accurately diagnosing abnormalities in cardiac structure.

body.p: What causes the “lub dub” sound that is typically associated with one heartbeat?

multiple_choice.choice: Closing of the atrioventricular and semilunar valves
Closing of the mitral and tricuspid valves
Closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves
Closing of the mitral and aortic valves

feedback.p: Correct. The atrioventricular valves are the mitral and tricuspid valves, and the semilunar valves are the aortic and pulmonary valves. Closing of the AV valves and the semilunar valves, respectively, result in the “lub dub” sound associated with one heartbeat.
Incorrect. These are the two atrioventricular valves, which together produce the first half of the “lub dub” sound.
Incorrect. These are the two semilunar valves, which together produce the second half of the “lub dub” sound.
Incorrect. While these two valves do contribute to the “lub dub” sound, there are two other valves that are also involved.

hint.p: Each sound is caused by the closing of a different set of valves.

feedback.p: Correct. The compression of these waves implies that there are more waves per minute, which indicates a higher than usual heart rate.
